body: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries. body: With dozens of entrepreneurs clamorously peddling a radical new technology to an eager and sometimes gullible public, Automobile Row may be thought of as the Silicon Alley of the early 20th century. But as names like Studebaker and Peerless faded from popular consciousness, so too did the memory of the bustling and often extravagant showrooms
title: POSTINGS: 3 Early Showrooms Are Named Landmarks; Surviving Stars From Auto Row

body: BRETT COOK-DIZNEY made a name for himself by hanging his spray-painted, graffiti-like murals around the city, where what he calls ''living museums'' comment on everything from Haitian immigration to cloning. Mr. Cook-Dizney takes it as a measure of his success that in many struggling Brooklyn neighborhoods, more people may have seen his hip-hop
title: COPING; A Hip-Hop Artist Brings It All Back Home

body: CONTEMPORARY art in New York is a half-empty, half-full situation. Depending on whom you listen to, it's either terminally confused and uncentered, or healthily, refreshingly diverse. (Personally, I think confusion is healthy, so I win either way.) Almost anyone would agree, though, that the art world is itself fragmented. There's a centralized
title: ART REVIEW; For Hikers Seeking Art, Brooklyn Is a Left Bank

body: A bouncer at a Brooklyn nightclub died early yesterday in a gun battle that erupted when he and a colleague turned away a group of men hoping to attend a birthday party, the police said. His fellow bouncer and two of the men denied entry were also injured in the fight. The confrontation was one of six unrelated shootings, three of them fatal,
title: 3 Men Are Shot to Death In Clashes Over Weekend

body: A TYPICAL Sunday in the Queens childhood of the Rev. James F. Fitzpatrick went something like this: Get up early in Ozone Park and put your good clothes on. Go to 9 a.m. Mass. title: PUBLIC LIVES; Bringing a Lifetime of Faith to a Tough Job

body: At New York City firehouses, time spent waiting is often time spent cooking. Firefighters (those with Italian blood especially, according to one Irish-American) have been known to trade shifts to be able to work with the best chefs, and some are so well known for their meals that a 1986 cookbook from a fire station in Harlem made the New York Times
title: For Firefighters, Team Effort On Thanksgiving Is Dinner

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; A Twofold Mission Of Piety and Pop

title: PUBLIC LIVES; Now (Still) Cleaning Up: Topps Company

title: METRO BRIEFING

body: TWO weeks after Vehronna Smith bought her five-story, five-apartment brownstone on Dean Street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, last March, she slumped onto the old, crooked hallway stairs, wept and said to herself, ''Oh God, what have I done?'' title: Keeping Homeowners in Their Homes

body: THE old warehouse on Auburn Avenue was long an eyesore, and Alton Evans, 40, can remember when it was worse. Just a few years ago, he said, the building sat gutted, a haven for transients and drug dealers. That was the mid-1990's in the central city neighborhood known as the Old Fourth Ward, and anything could happen. In those days, residents say,
title: A TALE OF TWO DOWNTOWNS; After Worst of Times, Building for the Best

body: Abdul Muhammad smiles when he recalls the days when the milkman delivered fresh milk and eggs to everybody's front stoop in the morning. He makes a living in a similar way, hauling sacks of frozen fish he buys wholesale from the Nation of Islam into private homes. But he has to wait until the light of day to make his rounds. Today, he says, crime
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE -- CITYPEOPLE; He Sells Fish Garnished With Blessings and Cheer

title: FOLLOWING UP; Appeals Continue for 2 Convicted in 1991 Unrest

title: Brooklyn Journal; For Orthodox, a Garden for Courting

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; A Modern Embellishment Seeks Harmony With a Beaux-Arts Jewel

title: THE SENATE CAMPAIGN: THE FIRST LADY; Mrs. Clinton Works Hard on Her Spontaneity

body: On a typical weekday a bus may be only a means of getting to work. But tomorrow, in Brooklyn at least, it will be much more: a nostalgic vehicle to transport you back to your childhood and to offer today's youngsters an extraordinary ride. This magical travel comes courtesy of the New York Transit Museum, which will hold its eighth annual Bus
title: FAMILY FARE; Trafficking In the Past

title: METRO BRIEFING

Lazio, the Republican opponent to Hillary Rodham Clinton, enthusiastically shaking the hand of Yasir Arafat during an official visit to the Middle East nearly two years ago. The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said
title: White House Enters Senate Race With Release of Photo of Lazio and Arafat

body: For Jeron Joseph, it was hard saying goodbye to the summer, no matter how fickle the weather. A high school junior, he was also worried about having to pass more and more Regents exams in order to graduate. But on opening day yesterday, he could not wait to see the inside of the Middle College High School in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the first new
title: Students Are Abuzz In Their New Building

Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton stepped off into their general election campaigns today. Mrs. Clinton bopped down Brooklyn's Eastern Parkway while Mr.
title: Campaigning On Main St. And to a Beat

body: As they have for years on Labor Day, tens of thousands of New Yorkers, and the politicians who court them, descended on Brooklyn yesterday to watch or take part in the West Indian American Carnival Parade in Crown Heights, with the city's largest street spectacle dampened only by a sudden downpour that brought a brief halt to the festivities. title: Unbowed, if Soggy, Parade Goes On

body: A Brooklyn man has been arrested and charged with attacking four young women as they jogged or walked alone in Park Slope and nearby neighborhoods over the weekend, the police said yesterday. The suspect, Michael Bowden, 30, was arrested in a surveillance operation quickly organized by the police to catch the attacker before he struck again, said
title: Man Held in Weekend Attacks On Four Women in Brooklyn

body: Fourteen people were injured when a city bus and a minivan collided in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, fire and transit officials said. The bus, which was traveling the B78 route through Crown Heights, collided with the minivan near Ralph Avenue and Fulton Street, said Firefighter James Spollen, a Fire Department spokesman. The accident took place
title: 14 Hurt in Collision of a Bus and a Minivan

title: Bitter Primary Contest Hits Ethnic Nerve Among Blacks

body: As the chairman of the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. has long been known for masterminding the strategies of a host of political races in his borough and beyond. And so the thinness of his re-election victory two years ago, by just 677 votes in the Democratic primary, was something of an embarrassment.
title: Assemblyman Says He's Fighting Harder in Rematch

title: For Many Immigrants, a Health Care System Underground

title: Making Roommates of Perfect Strangers

body: Divided by allegiance and an aisle, David Gottesman and Si Wachsberger awaited the vote of the Beachwood, Ohio, Planning and Zoning Commission on agenda item 96-63. title: The Jewish Tipping Point

body: Three years ago an experiment in artistic democracy began. And last week it ended. title: Arts Crusade Folds Its Tent At Harvard; A Playwright's Experiment In Democracy Didn't Rally the People

body: ON a breezy Saturday afternoon, Rawle George rode his bike into Prospect Park, weaved around the families barbecuing hot dogs, and coasted past a crowded Little League game. Stopping in a field of people flying kites and playing Frisbee, he scanned the scene until his eye hooked onto one object: a white ball being kicked into the air. Mr. George
title: Years Pass. The Game Endures.

title: Bricks, Mortar And Coalition Building

title: COPING; Where Streets Are the Threat To Scholars

body: Students in New York City performed only slightly better on a citywide mathematics test this year than last, with 68 percent still failing to meet tough new standards. title: Schools Show Slight Increase In Math Scores

body: The official term is ''supplemental adjustment,'' but opponents call it ''the poor tax.'' Whatever name is used, it is the surcharge that rent regulators have imposed on low-cost apartments in New York City in 14 of the last 17 years. The cumulative effect has been to sharply raise prices at the low end of the rental market, a study shows. The
title: Rent Board to Vote on Extending Much-Debated Surcharge

title: Match Made in Heaven: New Home for Old Torah

body: For years, New York City educators have assailed the state's school financing system as unfair, saying it provides the city with nearly $2,000 less per student than areas upstate and in the suburbs. title: Success of City School Pupils Isn't Simply a Money Matter

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Crown Heights Verdicts Challenged in Appeal

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT PARK; Bird Lovers Will Find a Home in a Beaux-Arts Boathouse

body: Flying over this country's bountiful rain forest in a noisy propeller plane seating nine people can unnerve the most seasoned traveler. title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Guyana Airline Owner Scents New Growth in Old Backwater

title: COPING; Rites of Passage To Nurture Values

title: City Hall to Use $54 Million To Add Day Care Subsidies

body: There's matzo, and there's matzo for Passover. Then there's matzo for Passover of a higher order. For years, most American Jews heeding the commandment to shun leavened bread during Passover have eaten the square, machine-made matzo sold as ''kosher for Passover.'' Not only is it unleavened bread, as all matzo is, but it has been produced with care
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Unleavened Bread for the Truly Observant

body: FOR almost 80 years, first in Russia and then in America, Dora Solganik of Cleveland has been performing the gefilte fish ritual for Passover: schlepping to the fish market, choosing the best fish ''by the look in its eyes,'' and transforming it into the quintessential Seder dish. Using a wooden bowl and a half-moon-shaped chopper, she cuts up the
title: Gefilte Fish: The Next Generation

body: IN America, more than 200,000 guns are traced by law enforcement each year. title: THE NATION; The Biography of a Gun

title: Black Writers Warn of Losing The Momentum

title: When Justice Hinges on Courage Of One Witness; A Bodega Owner and His Struggle With the Risks of Coming Forward

title: SHADES OF BLUE: A special report.; Diallo Case Yields More Nuanced View of Police

title: SPRING THEATER/VISIONS OF AMERICA; Bringing the High Drama of Real Life to the Stage

title: City Investigates Program, Citing Disproportionate Granting of Day Care Benefits

title: Reinstated Officer Is Renewed as a Candidate

title: The Shattered Lives Left by a Street War; Wheeled Prisons Bear Legacy Of Violence of a Crack Epidemic
